Looking at all pollsters' sites the average score is 41,67; while looking at past presidents it shows that they all have a decline at more or less a year after. With an exception on GWB due to the events during his presidency. Given the present crisis, he may stay above 40%.

At the time of this forecast FiveThirtyEight has his approval sitting at 41.8%. With a week left it seems statistically a certainty he will end up in the 2nd bucket. A < -1.8% move seems statistically impossible in a weeks time with his historic approval rating finding a floor around 41-42% and nothings clearing pointing to a collapse of support to the downside. Alternatively a > +3.2% move to the upside also seems statistically impossible. Even if some rally around the leader support is in place a 3.2% increase in a weeks time seems impossible in a time of such political division in the country.
Its only a few days and he is hovering in the low 40s.

As of 23 March, Biden's approval rating is 41.5%. The lowest so far this year is 40.4% on 27 Feb. The most recent highest (above 45%) is 45.3% in Sept 2021,  Question: What would cause Biden’s approval rating to plunge or rise in the next 1 week? From Google, it was mentioned that for the rating to increase, "Presidential approval ratings increase if there is a successful war going on at the time. War brings the country together with patriotism; this causes the people to be much more supportive of their president. Another factor is the health of the economy." For the rating to decrease, the three variables are inflation, unemployment and the budget deficit. They conclude that if the popularity functions are assumed to be stable throughout the period being observed that an increase in these three variables will lead to a decrease in the presidential popularity rate." Since inflation, unemployment and budget deficit are indicators with slower effects (we are looking at a week's time frame), the only factor that could dramatically affect the presidential approval rating is the possibility of the United States joining the Ru-Ukr war. If the US joins the war in the next week or so, there could be a increase in rating (rallying patriotism). However the probability of the US voluntarily joining the war in the next week remains low (I put it as 5%). Even so, the rating may not increase beyond 45% (I put it as a 50% chance) 50% of 5% is rounded up as 3%, which I distribute as 2% and 1% in the 45<X<50 and 50<X<55 baskets.
On the other hand, the effects of high oil/gas prices due to the war could have a continued decreasing effect on the rating (I put it as 5% that it could go below 40%)

Despite a post-state of the union jump, President Biden is back around 42%. Events in Ukraine could swing him up or down, but I'm increasing my odds for 40 to 45% given the nearness of the question's end date.

Unstable times always cause a reinforcement of support for an incumbent.  However I don’t think this will be large for Biden given the way US politics is at the moment.  It’s probably enough to keep his support above 45pc until end of March, with a small change to go over 50pc, but unlikely.

While inflation remains high and implications of Ukrainian situation continues to present uncertainty in gasoline and energy markets, continuing progress in other economic metrics seem to be holding up.

Reverting closer to a previous forecast. Seems that the recent big downward jump was a short-term fluctuation and that we are now back to our ‘regularly scheduled approval-rate programming’. Well over a percentage point of buffer, extreme stability of approval rates over the past months (in spite of everything going on) and only weeks to go now -> high confidence forecast.
There's been another uptick in Biden's approval rating in recent days. A random walk from here indicates that he ends up with lower than 40% only about 22% of the time.

Biden's approval rating as of this forecast is sitting near an all time low of 41.1% while in the midst of what is (hopefully) the tail end of COVIDs pandemic phase, the initial blitz of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the highest inflation we have seen in decades, sky high oil costs, and major stock indices in either correction(Dow, S&P500) or Bear market (Nasdaq) territory. While all of these present significant downside risks should they take a turn for the worse, I would argue that he it probably more likely close to his floor of support with a large group of hardcore partisans likely to always support him barring some major Black Swan event. With most of the people who are willing to switch having likely already moved against him I see the path of least resistance as higher. I will leave a 7% chance to cover cases where all the above situations remain an issue with one or more getting even worse for Biden. More likely I would expect a regression to the Mean as one or more of the listed situations shows sign of progressing towards a resolution. Especially if it appears that actions the US government was important in progressing towards a resolution. Above 50% before the end of March seems very unlikely as it would be such a drastic swing in such a short period of time. I am leaving a 5% possibility that some major crisis sparks a rally behind the flag effect (4% for 50-55%, 1% >55%). But do not see this as likely with how many hardcore Republican partisans likely to never approve of him. This leaves the 40% to 50% range. With how polarized US politics is at the moment things like approval ratings do not often swing quickly I would expect a smaller (-1 to 4%) regression to the mean rather than a larger one (5 to 10%).
Interested to see if there is a bounce after the state of the union or change due to Ukraine.

The US political scene is extremely polarized. Currently, they have excellent job growth and strong prospects going forward. Industry is responding to Chinese competition and ‘re-shoring’. The Infrastructure spending will start to kick in next year. Inflation globally is showing 5-6% annual rates and may climb, whether this is transitory or part of a longer term trend is unclear but the US is no worse than the global figures. Covid is yielding, slowly, to vaccines and now therapeutics. With this generally positive outlook there should be strong support for the government and Biden. It is not the case and polarization is the only explanation.  With Trump, another extremely polarizing figure, his popularity/favour ability rating never climbed above 50%, ever. It languished around 43%, where Biden sits, during his entire presidency. Biden can’t expect better. In the end, come Election Day, people will ask if they are better off, and if they are honest with themselves, they’ll acknowledge that they are and vote accordingly.

Passage of time. Biden’s rating is about as low as we’ve seen, but there seems to be a floor at this level, and we’re still basically 1/4 of a bin away from the boundary. Given how stable public opinion has been, and how long it tends to be before it changes, I’m feeling increasingly confident that we will see the Question resolve in bin #2. Outside credible chance that some new disaster or scandal could take us to bin #1, e.g. Ukraine, etc. but I don’t think it’s likely to matter enough, soon enough in the current hyper-polarized political climate.

Updating again since Biden's approval has risen to 41.7% (the better part of a percentage point). A Monte Carlo simulation of a random walk based on previous approval shifts suggests that, from today's 41.7% approval rating, Biden's approval has a ~26% of landing in bin 1 and a ~12% chance of landing in bin 3 [1], so I'll continue to take this as my "outside view". My "inside view" remains pretty much the same as my earlier forecast [2], but I still think it's possible that other problems outside of covid (e.g. Russia, inflation) will continue to cause problems for Biden's approval numbers.

I think the crowd median is a biased representation. I keep seeing rationales that find reasons that would bump up the rating and rarely see ones that call for the downgrading of Biden's approval rating. Perhaps my forecast is too low for bin 2, but I think some middleground between mine and the current median is appropriately acceptable. COVID news and otherwise topics not followed by the average American citizen shouldn't be weighted much. We saw previously how our expectations of COVID improvements or drawbacks didn't necessarily correlate with his approval.

Updating slightly from my last forecast as Biden's approval has fallen to 41.0%. My "inside view" remains pretty much the same as my previous forecast [2], but I do think it's possible that other problems outside of covid (e.g. Russia, inflation) will continue to cause problems for Biden's approval numbers.

Spring weather!

-no recent POTUS had an approval rating below 40% on day 434.  In sum, his approval rating is falling faster than I anticipated, and, on balance, I think there's going to be more downward pressure on it than upward.  I suspect his approval rating will bounce along at around 40% for the remainder of his term, which means that at any time he could be slightly below it.

A Monte Carlo simulation of a random walk based on previous approval shifts suggests that, from today's 41.3% approval rating, Biden's approval has a ~30% of landing in bin 1 and a ~10% chance of landing in bin 3 [1], so I'll take this as my "outside view". As for my "inside view", I generally agree with @jleibowich 's last comment [2] that falling covid cases will likely bolster Biden's approval rating. Also, as per @Anneinak 's previous comments, it would be rare for a president to have an approval rating less than 40% this early on although Biden is close now and it did happen for Clinton and Trump [3].

Biden's approval on FiveThrtyEight is at 42.0% this morning. A random walk in approval ratings from here based on Biden's approval movement history means getting back above 50% by the end of March is now at less than half a percent in the Monte Carlo simulations. Meanwhile,  it puts the "Lower than 40.0%" bucket is at ~23%. While a president going below 40% this early would be unusual, Trump was at around 35% [1] after his first year, so it would not be unprecedented. I'm still biasing on the positive side of what the Monte Carlo simulation suggests based on my suspicion that as Omicron abates, Biden's approval numbers will improve. The last three Democrats had almost a 60% approval rating after their first year in office. As of 13 January President Biden's approval rating is ~45%.  With looming international issues such as Ukraine-Russia conflict, and China-Taiwan, and what the US is prepared to do, I don't see any event within the next 2.5 months that would make it go up. Because of ongoing COVID testing issues, as one example, I do see a situation where it can easily go down a few more points and perhaps under 40%.

President Biden's current policies are not currently effective at raising the approval rate.  Public gaffes by both POTUS and VPOTUS are alienating the public on both sides.  Significant issues such as COVID are worsening with no end in sight.  As the election season ramps up, Republican attacks will almost certainly have an effect on public opinion among undecided voters.
Adjusting to reflect current polling and the difficult economic environment ahead.

My "inside view" is that by the end of March, within the United States, the Omicron wave will have largely petered out and Biden's poll numbers will improve as a result. My "outside view" is informed by a Monte Carlo simulation based on Biden's previous polling shifts.  Putting the two together, I stared from the MC simulation and made minor adjustments to be slightly less bearish than the crowd in my forecast of Biden's approval rating.
MC Simulation : { 
    "Lower than 40.0%" : 19.0%, 
    "Between 40.0% and 45.0%, inclusive": 60.66%,
    "Higher than 45.0% but lower than 50.0%": 19.49%,
    "Between 50.0% and 55.0%, inclusive": 0.84%,
    "Higher than 55.0%": 0.01%,
}

Moderating further toward the crowd based on the "inside view" that several events recently broke in Biden's favor. I also want to see  what will happen with the bills he's backing. My "outside view" is still largely informed by the simulation as described in my previous comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1351171

For my "outside view", my simulation of a random walk in approval ratings suggests the odds are as follows:
"Lower than 40.0%": 25%
"Between 40.0% and 45.0%, inclusive": 44.25%
"Higher than 45.0% but lower than 50.0%": 25.75%
"Between 50.0% and 55.0%, inclusive": 4.5%
"Higher than 55.0%": 0.5%
For my "inside view", I'm trying to balance considerations such as whether Biden has a support floor / ceiling and also whether there are limiting factors on how far his support can move in either direction due to partisanship. I suspect his ceiling is in the high 50's under normal circumstances although extraordinary events could change this. Meanwhile, I suspect his floor is somewhere in the lower 30's under normal circumstances. With that said, it may be harder and harder to move toward the extremes of this range as each layer of additional change is more difficult to move than the previous. For that reason, I'm giving the 40-45 and 45-50 buckets significantly higher weight than the random walk simulation would suggest.

Adjusting probabilities to account for a few comparative observations (new to me, apologies in advance to those who've already been watching things very carefully for a long time):
- Biden's "August Slide" downwards may not be completely over, but in the past few weeks seems to have slowed significantly / stabilized, with the ultimate low perhaps to be expected in the ~43-44% range (if it goes lower without first rebounding upwards significantly, that would suggest the slide isn't yet over after all at the time of this forecast).
- The previous president had a remarkably flat and stable approval rating, in spite of a near-continuous string of bad news / good news (depending on the kind of news channel followed). The news flow from that presidency--because of its seriousness and impact on a variety of major issues (foreign, domestic, economic, etc.)--almost certainly included some events that would've very likely caused much more significant swings in pre-2000's US public opinion. The presidency before that also had a very low amount of variation in approval ratings, although arguably there were far fewer "shocks" to the political system.
- The trends of Biden's and Obama's approval ratings during the first year of their respective presidencies seem visually fairly similar. Perhaps one reference scenario to keep an eye on might be: "Evolution of Biden's approval ratings will closely track those of Obama's, but be offset downwards by 6-7%"... All of these ideas are suggesting to me that Biden may now be approaching his "approval-rating floor", and approval won't go much lower, unless pushed down further by some future black swan event. The most likely outcome to this question still seems (to me) that approval will hover somewhere in the middle three bins in a scenario where COVID recedes in the future, and the US economy recovers, without further major shocks in the timeframe of interest.

Outside View: 
50 years of data indicates 54.15% average for Presidents at the 434 day mark. Remove the two “black swan” events (First Gulf War and 9/11) and its a 47% average. Cyclical rate of “black swan” event at the 434 day mark is once every 20 years. Covid-19 occurred at the 19 year mark so I will count that as our 20-year "black swan" event. As a result, 47% average reigns supreme. Inside View: 
Congressional Budget Office is expecting a 7.4% GDP growth in CY21 and 3% in CY22. Afghanistan, by this point, is 10 months removed. Infrastructure bill has popular support via polling. Covid-19 policies continue to garner popular support and Delta variant is expect to decline by winter 2021. Highest uncertainty resides with the occurrence of another “black swan” event and the potential for the administration to counter an ineptitude narrative.
Over the last four administrations, the average approval rating hasn't topped 50%.  Much of the approval rating is tied to the economy and it looks like a storm is brewing on that front.

Approval rating should probably stay within a fairly narrow range (middle three bins) if no extraordinary events occur shortly before 31 March 2022. Even if a significant event or two did occur several months ahead of this date that caused a large up- or down-swing in the approval rating, I would intuitively expect public opinion in our highly polarized US political climate  to slowly return to a “normal” level over time.

Since 1953, approval ratings for the 12 US Presidents prior to Biden have ranged from a high of 70.1% to a low of 41.1%.  Ratings:  <40% = 0,   40 – 45% = 1,   >45 – <50% = 5,  50 – 55 % = 1,  >55% = 5  Average Rating: 53.26.  Average Democrat Rating: 56.45  If President Kennedy is removed from evaluation, average is 53.72.   President Biden's approval rating has varied from 53% to 45.6% since Jan 2021.  This period includes the turmoil due to the Afghanistan withdrawal, COVID, refugee crisis, and multiple natural disasters. The next 12-months will include additional challenges caused by a rising China, climate change, US budget disagreements, disputes within the Democratic party, and partisan politics.

Looming stock market problems related to a possible government shutdown and defaulting on national debt are currently pushing down approval rating in the aftermath of Afghanistan departure.  That aftermath has a high potential to be diminished in voters' minds.  However, the midterm elections in Nov 22 suggest the opposition party and candidates will begin reminding voters of all the negative aspects, in the worst possible terms, of Biden's term so far.  There are also few anticipated events that will help Biden raise his numbers.  Biden's temperament, track record, and risk aversion leading up to the midterms will limits big moves that might reduce approval ratings even though they could raise it.  He is likely to seek a stabilization in the current downward trend in the short term (Sep-Dec 21) then focus on not committing any gaffes that would drive it down further.

Many great points have been made in the comments. My personal weighing is that
+ There likely a fairly solid base of support, making bin 1 very unlikely and bin 2 fairly unlikely
- Notwithstanding the above, here's always a chance of some absolutely god-awful decision that tanks his ratings
+ There's also a chance of some fabulous decisions, though unlikely to make dedicated disapprovers change their mind
+ The effects of Afghanistan are in the rearview mirror, so we might expect some degree of return to previous ratings
Keeping the spirit of my old forecast but factoring in some of the forecasters' confidence in an approval rating of greater than 45%. If you continue the latest trend, bin one gets 50–70% chance.

Presidential approval ratings are increasingly a market of partisan identity moreso than actual personal evaluation of Presidential job performance. The odds that many people who voted for Biden will relinquish their approval of him seems low. That said, approval numbers often tend to dip below midterms. In the coming months, this trend could be mitigated for Biden based on a few factors: 
1) Afghanistan news is relegated increasingly far back in the rearview mirror. 
2) Vaccination mandates will only have a political effect on people who already disapprove of the Biden admin already. Yet vaccine-hesitant components of the Democratic base will, I suspect, not punish Biden for it in surveys. 
2.5) As vaccination rates climb, even by mandate, cases will drop and economic activity will pick up as masking/lockdown impositions recede again. This will re-rally Dems and and his "soft" voters to saying they approve of him. There could well be a 15% chance Biden does face and bungle a major national crisis, which would be what plows his approval rating down below 45% or even 40%.

Barring something completely unexpected, President Biden will likely have about the same approval rating through at least the next 6 months. When you look at historic trends in Presidential approval rating, they generally stay within a range of 5 to 10 points over a similar period of time, again barring crisis or significant events to shape American opinion.

I don't see where Biden's numbers go up from here. Passing more legislation will probably just invite more backlash. Republicans will be starting to gear up attack ads to run against him during the midterms (and not just the Dem party). There will likely be more bad news from Afghanistan. The media seems on hair-trigger alert to criticize the Biden admin now since Afghanistan (the Biden admin also seems curiously bad at diplomacy more generally, see the reaction to the UK-AUS-US submarine deal). There will likely be more health problems and issues with VP Harris. All told, I don't see approval drifting up over 50% and it very well could go lower than 40%.

I'm guessing the inflation/Afghanistan/Delta stuff will have faded some by resolution next year, so I think the current dip is semi-temporary. That said it looks like the trend is a slow decline, so I'm guessing Biden will have a slight bounce back followed by a steady decline which I'm guessing will be similar to Obama's trend.

Currently 45.9%. Past history would suggest that big moves are unusual, with the variance being more on the upside (war, emergency) than on the downside. however, the current highly-polarized environment may pull us more towards the middle Here's my take:  A: <40%: seems virtually impossible

We are at 46% approve right now (September 13th). Reason to believe this is a low point. Historically we have seen approval revert to some mean and we have (1) Afghanistan coverage (2) COVID uncertainty + Delta.  From January through June this year his approval bounced between 53-55%. I think that was likely the higher water mark of realistic approval because: (1) president's typically lose popularity as they attempt to pass their agenda (2) we were in vaccine rollout, COVID down, pre-Delta times (3) juxtaposition to the end of Trump presidency.  This will be at the 435th day of his presidency. Recent comparisons for that are...
* Trump @ 40.5 (about where he stayed rest of presidency)
* Obama @ 48.5 (about where he stayed rest of term)
* W Bush @ 73.8 (rally around flag)
* Clinton @ 50.9 (up + down with scandals, but his baseline was likely above 50 - good comp for Biden)
* HW Bush @ 73.5 (rally around flag)
* Reagan @ 46 (would go up later in presidency)
* Carter @ 50.1 (continued support from recovery from nixon/ford - it fell off a cliff after this) Also thinking about baseline - we have party affiliation at ~48/49 Democrat vs 40 Republican this past spring https://news.gallup.com/poll/343976/quarterly-gap-party-affiliation-largest-2012.aspx. Together, it's pretty clear that the most likely range is 45-55 reflecting our polarization. Let's think about the tails to decide...
* >55% is most likely possible only a 'rally around the flag' situation. While Biden flirted with 55 right after inauguration, it seems unlikely to reset there as dust settled. Carter, Bush HW, Bush W all had swings like that (3 of past 7 presidents) but Carter's was short-lived and timing leaves me with that at 6%
* <40% would require a different black swan event, more like Mueller investigation in Trump. And even he was only there for a few months. I put that at half as likely, 3%. 
* 40-45 is only slightly below his 46% now... but it would require many more Democrats souring on Biden early in his term. Obama spent just a couple weeks below 45 prior to midterms. I rate this at 8%. I think the crowd is too high on this! Okay, so I have 83% left in the likely set between 45 - 55. It seems his natural approval will sit at just around 50, even losing a bit since his 53-55. I think the Carter + Clinton comps are interesting. Originally I had 50-55 as higher, but the crowd + Nate Silver's comments on this made me give 45-50 a 20% edge at 45% (to 38% for 50-55)

Based on the past presidents, below 40% seems like a low chance, but could potentilly see something in the high 30s. Probably safe to stick most of the forecast in the 45-55 range, as it seems like most presidents don't break out of that range unless there is something major that shifts in the country.

His new policies are going to help defeat the COVID variants and the fight against them is unpopular with a major majority. Getting our economy back up and running, which depends on vaccinations and fighting COVID will be the work of the Democratic Party. The Republican Party's hands off approach (or worse) will fail. There's really nothing else to say.

I think @Anneinak has the right thinking, as do others comparing Biden to previous presidents. In addition, I think someone made the point that I hadn't considered that the polarized nature of the country could prevent extreme lows and highs. If we just do a simple trend down, its definitely bin #1. But as we know, the complex world isn't linear. I'm trending to add more pp to the first two bins and subtract from the others.

These questions sure do give me stuff to think about! I'm looking back at my notes from just yesterday, and I can't recreate one of my values.  hm.  WHAT was I thinking?!  So, I tossed it out. I'm also troubled by how the values for HST threw everything out of whack. So, I re-calculated average change from day 234 to day 434 for all POTUS (excluding HST) = a decrease of .1%  and Dem POTUS (excluding HST) = a decrease of 1.5.  That would put JB at 43.8-45.2 Averaging those values, along with the ones I calculated yesterday (excluding the one I can't recreate!) I get 42-41-16-1-0
In the meantime, the Wise Ones I'm following now average  5-33-4-14-1 And the crowd is now 6-44-44-6-0 And 538 says he's up .5% to 45.8%. So, I'm still far more pessimistic about JB's approval rating than the crowd or my Wise Ones, and so far the polls are not moving in the direction I'm predicting they'll go. hm.  Do I really think JB's approval rating will be in DJT territory when this question closes?  More to think about!
Today on "ABC This Week" Nate Silver said that in his opinion Biden's lower approval rating is probably "the new normal."  I'm questioning my previous forecast, and lowering my median forecast.
Its a trainwreck and getting worse.
Refer to my discussion here (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1331560) for rationale, will look into potential catalysts in either direction soon

Biden support even after the Afghanistan withdrawal has not dropped below 45pc and it already looks like his approval is increasing again.  This suggests to me that there may be a floor in support around 45pc.  I can’t see support going over 55pc, so the mostly likely think is it will hover in the 45 to55pc range.  I’m weighting slightly on the 45-50pc range on the assumption that people are more likely to be disappointed in Biden regardless.

In terms of extremes, could Biden slip below 40%? Given recent issues with vaccinations, Delta and now Afghanistan, his popularity has certainly waned, but equally 45% could now be factoring in most of the bad news, and I think he'll recover some ground after bottoming out around 42% (I can't see him being less popular than Trump). 
Above 55%?  Obama struggled with this after a brief 'honeymoon' period above 60% and I think Biden may follow a similar but less extreme pattern; he's not as charismatic, but equally my impression is that he's not as polarising, and he's walking quite a tight path to achieve any gains, so I think his popularity may stay in a narrower band. Politics seems even more divided now than when Obama started, so anything much above 50% within 6 months looks ambitious.
As for the middle ground, a lot will likely depend on the economy and the fading Delta curve through the end of the year. Barring another new covid variant, political upturn or war (which covers quite a lot, fair enough)  I suspect everyone will feel slightly more positive into next Spring and he'll be rated marginally higher than now.

Using historic approval rating changes between days 1, 234, and 407 through Carter, and ignoring Bush W's extreme increase as an outlier, the likely range for Biden's approval rating is 29.9%-56.9%. Plugging that in as two stddev yields this probability distribution.

This article in FiveThirtyEight compares Trump's approval after one year in office with that of previous presidents.  https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-year-in-trumps-approval-rating/ Political polarization has both lowered the ceiling and raised the floor of approval ratings.  Voters have become more tribal, backing a president of their party even when things go badly, and opposing a president of the other party even when things are going relatively well.  For this reason I do not believe Biden's approval will fall below 40%.  A COVID strain worse than Delta could prove me wrong on the negative side.  Likewise the odds of achieving approval greater than 55% are low.  Progress on COVID and a strong economy could make me wrong on the positive side.

I hope to do better on this question than I did on the last one about Biden's approval rating.  LOL! This initial forecast is based on some playing with numbers.   Looking at the 538 charts for other presidents, I calculated how much the approval rating for each had changed from day 234 until day 434.  GOP presidents, on average, gained .9%.  Dem presidents, on average, lost 6.6%*.   If I ignored party, the average loss was 2.6%.   *(I did not exclude any as "outliers" --HST was a huge drag on Dem averages! while GWB gave GOP averages a big boost!--because of extraordinary events, since an extraordinary event could occur during the time frame of this question.) Given that JB started off at 45.3.0%, that would put his rating at day 434  between 42.7 (based on the average for all POTUS) and 38.7 (based on Dem averages). Looking at it in another way, the approval rating of 6 of 13 POTUS improved an average of 8.7% between days 234 & 434, and the approval rating of 7 out of 13 fell an average of 12.2%.    That would give JB a 46% chance of an approval rating higher than 45.3 and a 54% chance of an approval rating of less than 45.3, with maximums and minimums around 54.0 and 33.1%. (Unless I'm all scrambled up,  which is quite possible!) Yet another way to look at is that JB's lost 9% in the last 200 days, so if he's on a straight-line decline, that would put him at 36.3% in 200 more days. How to translate all of this into a forecast?  Because Biden isn't a charismatic leader and congressional margins are so slim, making passage of big legislation difficult, I think his rating will not be volatile. I averaged my 4 methods of forecasting his final rating range . . .  Then I looked at the crowd's forecast.  Hm, with my forecasts at  68-20-11-1-0 I'm significantly more pessimistic.  That might be ok because on the last question the crowd was too optimistic. Then, I looked at the average of the forecasts of folks I'm following (7-23-28-38-4) and I'm more pessimistic than them, too.  hm.  That shakes my confidence more, but not enough to change my forecast. . . yet.  LOL! The next time I look at this question I'll consider the domestic political events that might impact this question, then maybe the global political events and then the domestic & global economic events.

The most striking thing about Biden’s approval ratings is the degree of partisan polarization. For the first 200 days, it was stable (with a modest downward trend): it started around 54 and reached 50. 

But then right before Afghanistan (around day 200) it dropped couple of points, and with Afghanistan debacle - which I don't think will ever fade altogether, not the least because of the number of casualties in Kabul Airport that US had - it dropped couple of more points so that it's now at 45.2%.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/

That is, in about 33 days it dropped 5 points. I don't think he may ever catch up. 
He's not by any means charismatic. And he's going to mostly focus on domestic issues - if ever such thing existed. 
Recently with his call to China he obviously suggested that no confrontation is wished.  I suspect a similar trend with Obama for Biden, except that Biden started 10 points lower, and his drop is steeper. At around day 430 (the deadline in question) Obama was about 47.7%. I gather Biden won't go higher than this. 

Furthermore, Trump was fairly stable all around 42%. So I don't think Biden will go bellow 40.  => It will oscillate around 45%. But I'd suspect it to be in the lower band (i.e., 40 to 45) as opposed to the upper category (i.e., 45 to 50). 
One doesn't have to downplay the rising inflation in the US:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/higher-inflation-is-here-to-stay-for-years-economists-forecast-11626008400 Maybe at the end of his term he'll reach around 51%  by the way, does anyone think he'll be elected for 2nd term? That could be a nice question :)

So from day 234 to day 436... Obama dropped ~3% and continued to slide until end of year 2; Bush had a big 9/11 jump then slid;  Clinton jumped 10% before sliding again; HW slid unless there was a war; Reagan slid ~6%; Carter slid ~6%. Broadly speaking, unless there's a war or terrorist attack, he's probably going to slide 3-6%. Democratic presidents seem less likely to start something, so that's less likely. The only real hope for an upswing is that the pessimism around Afghanistan is over by then (short attention spans and all). Past that; it's the economy, stupid. Markets are riding high and cracks are showing, both economically and with pandemic response, pretty much on a global scale. I'm not optimistic things will be better in 6 months than they are now, so it's most likely he'll slide. Frankly, from an outside perspective, he seems to be falling a bit flat and that doesn't bode well for his approval rating either. Recent history indicates that a more polarized electorate is more critical, so he'll probably be below historical averages regardless. I'll go ~60% in the 40-45 box and think its more likely to be above than below, then will weight out from there.

By then the Afghanistan thing will be forgotten, which puts upward pressure on his approval ratings over time. The Covid situation should also be significantly better. It's unknowable what future crises are coming, of course. But assuming I'm right on the Afghanistan thing and Covid, the natural partisan leanings of Americans should put Biden back into the 50-55 range.
